subject: Re: [junit] How to test an EJB?

messageBody:
My advice is to test as much as possible outside of the EJB context.

The common starting point is a stateless session bean, I assume that is
where you want to start:

The most common mistake (IMO) when developing EJB:s is that you tighthly
couple your businesslogic
to the EJB model. Think of the EJB model as a host, an environment for your
application to run in. The benefits
here is resource pooling versioning, handling lots of transactions,
threading issues and generally things you
don't want to care about. Your business logic should be testable outside
that model. When you're unit testing
you have no need for handling lots of simultanious requests so leave that
out of the picture until you write system
tests, system tests are different in nature and requires different tools (I
think this is where EJBUnit comes in I might be wrong
about that I haven't used it)

We use Spring, with the spring model, a session bean becomes an empty shell
that delegates to your business objects defined within your spring-context.

Wether you use spring or not, the same pattern still applies, let the
application
container take care of the application container stuff (life cycle events,
pooling, etc), trust
your container to do that well and test your business objects outside of the
session beans.

If you are using CMP:s beans (look carefully at the alternative persistance
solutions here if you havn't already picked one)
you can inject mock home interfaces to your business logic classes which
gives a quite nice abstraction to the hairy details.

Once again, Spring provides quite a lot of goodies in the EJB-context so do
have a look at it, it is well worth the small effort.

I hope this helps, ask if anything is not clear.
Regards
Joakim Ohlrogge
